title: What Is Beyoncé’s Definitive Album?
abstract: With the superstar’s seventh solo studio album, “Renaissance,” due Friday, our critics and reporters debate which work from her past reveals the most about her artistic vision.

multimedia.copyright: Kevin Mazur/Getty Images for Global Citizen Festival: Mandela 100
Kevin Mazur/Getty Images for Global Citizen Festival: Mandela 100

title: The Hosts of ‘5-4’ Never Trusted the Supreme Court
abstract: With public confidence in the top judicial body at a record low, a leftist podcast is preaching to a growing choir.

multimedia.caption: For the three hosts of the “5-4” podcast, hating the high court is nothing new. In fact, it’s something of a calling.
For the three hosts of the “5-4” podcast, hating the high court is nothing new. In fact, it’s something of a calling.

title: Berlin Biennale Wrestles With Big Issues (and Itself)
abstract: A powerful and relentlessly political exhibition takes on all the world’s crises — at the risk of conceptual overload.

multimedia.caption: “… and to Those North Sea Waves Whispering Sunken Stories (II),” by Sammy Baloji, on view at the Akademie der Künste as part of the Berlin Biennale.

title: Maggie Rogers’s Higher Calling
abstract: Musicians often talk about seeking the divine in their work. The 28-year-old singer-songwriter went to Harvard to study it as she made her second major-label album, “Surrender.”

multimedia.caption: “I wanted to build a framework for myself, for how to keep art sacred,” Maggie Rogers said of her detour to Harvard Divinity School during the pandemic.
multimedia.copyright: OK McCausland for The New York Times

title: Comics That Read Top to Bottom Are Bringing in New Readers
abstract: The explosion of web comics has been driven by tapping into an audience the industry had long overlooked: young, female readers.
byline: By George Gene Gustines and Matt Stevens

multimedia.caption: Digital comics have found new audiences. Ken Kim, Webtoon’s chief executive for North America, behind a character head from the comic series “Yumi’s Cells.”

title: Review: ‘The Silent Woman,’ an Opera About Putting on an Opera
abstract: Bard SummerScape unveiled a rare staging of Richard Strauss’s opera, composed amid the Nazis’ rise to power.

multimedia.caption: Jana McIntyre (Aminta) in Richard Strauss’s “The Silent Woman” (Die Schweigsame Frau) at Bard SummerScape.

title: ‘Seagull’ Review: Blurring the Lines of Fiction
abstract: Elevator Repair Service’s Chekhov revival has promising ideas about art, experimentation and truth, but the production inevitably falls flat, our critic writes.

title: Review: Finding the Heat in ‘Sacred Earth’
abstract: At Ragamala Dance Company’s nature-themed performance at BRIC Celebrate Brooklyn!, the strongest connection was between music and dance, our critic writes.

multimedia.caption: Ragamala Dance Company’s “Sacred Earth” is about correspondences between human emotions and the natural environment.

title: Bob Rafelson, Director of ‘Five Easy Pieces,’ Dies at 89
abstract: A central figure in the New Hollywood movement, he was also the co-creator of the TV pop group the Monkees and featured it in a movie, “Head.”

multimedia.caption: The director Bob Rafelson in 1987. A skilled navigator of the rapidly shifting pop-culture landscape of the 1960s, he was a producer of “Easy Rider.”
multimedia.copyright: Photo by Doris Thomas/Fairfax Media via Getty Images

title: Edward Feiner, 75, Dies; Revolutionized the Look of Federal Buildings
abstract: As the government’s chief architect, he prioritized good design in the construction of hundreds of courthouses and office buildings.

multimedia.caption: Edward A. Feiner in 2015. In his long career at the General Services Administration, he oversaw the construction of new government buildings and the renovation of old ones.
Edward A. Feiner in 2015. In his long career at the General Services Administration, he oversaw the construction of new government buildings and the renovation of old ones.

title: Conductor Dies After Collapsing During Performance in Munich
abstract: Stefan Soltesz was in the middle of Richard Strauss’s “The Silent Woman” when he fell from his podium shortly before the end of the first act.

multimedia.caption: Stefan Soltesz is the fourth conductor to collapse midperformance in Munich since the early 1900s.
Stefan Soltesz is the fourth conductor to collapse midperformance in Munich since the early 1900s.
Stefan Soltesz is the fourth conductor to collapse midperformance in Munich since the early 1900s.

title: A Novelist Says a Movie Fails to Credit Her. The Film World Shrugs.
abstract: Geling Yan says that she is owed a screen credit for the Chinese film “One Second” — and that companies bringing it to Western audiences are complicit in censoring her.

multimedia.caption: The writer Geling Yan has pushed for her novel “The Criminal Lu Yanshi” to be recognized in the film that it helped inspire.
The writer Geling Yan has pushed for her novel “The Criminal Lu Yanshi” to be recognized in the film that it helped inspire.

title: The Times’s Theater Critic Reviews Stratford’s New Theater
abstract: The Stratford Festival in Ontario opened a glamorous new theater last month that prioritizes the theater itself, not just what surrounds it.

title: Perry Rubenstein, Gallerist Convicted of Embezzlement, Dies at 68
abstract: He took his growing art business from Manhattan to Los Angeles, but it soon fell apart. Then, in 2016, he was arrested.

multimedia.caption: The gallerist Perry Rubenstein in 2007. He opened a gallery in Chelsea in 2004, then made waves seven years later when he announced that he was moving his operation to Los Angeles.
The gallerist Perry Rubenstein in 2007. He opened a gallery in Chelsea in 2004, then made waves seven years later when he announced that he was moving his operation to Los Angeles.

title: That Voice You’re Hearing? It Might Be Hers.
abstract: Julia Whelan is one of the most in-demand audiobook narrators working today. With her novel, “Thank You for Listening,” she’s telling a story of her own.

title: Taurean Blacque, Actor Best Known for ‘Hill Street Blues,’ Dies at 82
abstract: He received an Emmy nomination for his work as Detective Neal Washington, a character he strove to portray as something other than “that hip, jive Black man.”

title: ‘Cannabis!’ Review: Preaching to the Partaking Choir
abstract: This vaudevillian show at La MaMa in Manhattan is like a party where weed is the guest of honor, thrown by ardent, uncritical hosts.

multimedia.caption: Baba Israel in “Cannabis! A Viper Vaudeville” at La MaMa in Manhattan. He conceived the show and serves as its Magical Mystical M.C.

title: The Jan. 6 Hearings Did a Great Service, by Making Great TV
abstract: Investigating a threat to democracy was always going to be important. But this time, it also managed to be buzzworthy.
org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

multimedia.caption: The Jan. 6 hearings have amounted to an unusual but captivating eight-episode summer series by embracing elements common to any good TV drama.

title: Review: A New Opera Tells an Original Story With an Open Heart
abstract: “Castor and Patience,” a work by Gregory Spears and Tracy K. Smith with an intense yet relaxed score, premieres at Cincinnati Opera.

multimedia.caption: Reginald Smith Jr. and Jennifer Johnson Cano in “Castor and Patience.” The opera’s vocal lines draw us close to characters in a rending situation: here, a Black family split by disagreement over whether to sell part of a precious plot of land.

Reginald Smith Jr. and Jennifer Johnson Cano in “Castor and Patience.” The opera’s vocal lines draw us close to characters in a rending situation: here, a Black family split by disagreement over whether to sell part of a precious plot of land.

title: The Best of Late Night This Week 🌙
abstract: The heat wave in Europe, Jennifer Lopez and Ben Affleck’s big news, and President Biden’s coronavirus infection were among many topics the late-night hosts discussed this week.

title: After Making a Splash in Manhattan, an Artist Gets His Due Back Home
abstract: The designer Stephen Sprouse, known for his Day-Glo jumpsuits and graffiti-infused formal wear, is the subject of a rock ’n’ roll-inspired showcase in Indiana, where he grew up.

multimedia.caption: Sprouse grafted a punk sensibility onto many his creations, including, top, a dress designed for Kate Moss to wear in MTV’s 1996 “Choose or Lose” voting campaign.

title: Tom Sachs: Rocket Man to Renaissance Man
abstract: The artist is selling NFTs, designing Nikes, exploring outer space (sort of) and uncorking three concurrent shows in Seoul.

multimedia.caption: The artist Tom Sachs prepares a rocket for launch in Chicago in July. After 16 public launches in the last year, he is ending them, “so that we can focus on the next chapter, which is world-building.”

title: ‘Nope,’ Eadweard Muybridge and the Story of ‘The Horse in Motion’
abstract: Is the rider in the 19th-century photographic experiments really unknown, as Jordan Peele’s film implies? It’s complicated.
